abstract.p: Messengers Style, book by photographer Philippe Bialobos and fashion historian Valerie Steele, describes apparel worn by New York City's bicycle messengers; photos (Pulse column) (S)

block.p: Fashion feeds on the outrageous, the marginal, even the outright menacing. And it often draws vitality from the outlaw style embodied by New York's City's ubiquitous bicycle messengers. In ''Messengers Style'' (Assouline, $24.95), the photographer Philippe Bialobos and the fashion historian Valerie Steele look at the insolent, idiosyncratic get-ups created by those urban couriers on wheels. In their photos and text, the two identify the influence that members of this funky subculture wield on fashion at large. Ninja, pilot, punk, weird prophet -- these are just a few of the oddball personas messengers have assumed, and civilians have been quick to adopt their accessories, including chain belts and tinted aviator specs, studded wristbands stacked like bangles, cell phones and, of course, the trusty messenger bag.
In ''Dark Angel,'' the new Fox television series, Jessica Alba spins a sexy variation on the theme, playing a messenger dressed to thrill in a curve-clutching jacket and jeans.

Ninja, pilot, punk, weird prophet -- these are just a few of the oddball personas messengers have assumed, and civilians have been quick to adopt their accessories, including chain belts and tinted aviator specs, studded wristbands stacked like bangles, cell phones and, of course, the trusty messenger bag.

Which brings up a final reason messengers are trendsetters: ''Today,'' Ms. Steele points out, ''the hard body has become the ultimate fashion accessory.''
